statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: California 61, Pepperdine 58
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- Richard Midgley wasn't feeling well and wasn't shooting well, either. Still, he was the player Pepperdine coach Paul Westphal wanted to see holding the ball with the game on the line. For good reason. Throughout his career at California, Midgley has made a habit of hitting big shots at critical times for the Bears. Thursday night against the Waves, he did it again. Midgley's 3-pointer at the buzzer following a wild scramble for a loose ball lifted California to a 61-58 win over Pepperdine in the championship game of the Golden Bear Classic. "Richard was fatigued (and) under the weather ... but it wasn't going to deny him," said California coach Ben Braun. "He just needed some time and got it. It was a huge shot." One that nearly didn't come. The Bears and Waves were both scrambling for a loose ball in the waning seconds of the game when California's David Paris went to the floor and grabbed possession. Paris quickly dished the ball to teammate Martin Smith, who then found Midgley standing open and alone just beyond the 3-point arc. Midgley, who had missed nine of his first 10 shots from the floor, never hesitated with the ball in his hands, sinking a 3-pointer to win the game and give the Bears the tournament title for the eighth time in 12 years. "It was a great play by David to get the loose ball," said Midgley, who finished with a team-high 14 points. "Marty just found me wide open." Westphal, whose team lost for the third time in its last four games following a seven-game winning streak, knew that meant trouble for his Waves (8-4). "The last guy in the world we wanted to see standing there holding the ball," said Westphal, "was Richard Midgley." Neither the win nor the winning basket came easy for California (7-3), which shot just 34.6 percent from the floor. The Bears also missed half of their 36 free throw attempts but overcame the Waves' hustle with critical shooting down the stretch. In addition to Midgley's key 3-pointers, the Bears also got a clutch 3 from Martin Smith and a long jumper from Marquise Kately in the game's final minutes. Glen McGowan scored 26 points and grabbed 12 rebounds to pace Pepperdine, which led for most of the game before going cold in the final five minutes of the game. Kately had 12 points for the Bears (7-3) in his return after serving a one-game suspension for what California coach Ben Braun termed "failure to meet a team responsibility." Dominic McGuire added 10 points and a career-high nine rebounds. "This is probably our worst offensive performance of the year, but as I told our team, there are nights when you're going to struggle," Braun said. "We got to the free throw line, that was the good news. We just couldn't convert. But we did manage to keep our composure in the second half." Pepperdine led the entire first half and most of the second half, with McGowan scoring from all over. The Waves' forward went 6-for-7 at the free throw line, all in the second half, and was the lone Pepperdine player in double figures. California missed its first nine shots from the field and didn't score until Devin Hardin's short one-handed jumper with 15:55 left in the first half. By then, Pepperdine had already built an eight-point lead and was controlling the tempo of the game, forcing the Bears into a pace they weren't comfortable with. The Waves led 16-8 midway through the first half before California slowly crept back into the game. A 3-pointer from Kately and a lay-up from Rod Benson tied the game at 20. But the Bears struggled at the free throw line, missing seven of eight attempts in the final 3:30 of the first half, and went into halftime trailing 29-23.
